div.p: Friendly and dearly beloved lord and Christian brother, from the recent letter of Hans Tscharner, I have clearly understood your and his opinion regarding my son Titus and thank you both most sincerely, and I am pleased with your opinion. Therefore, I am sending the boy to you once again, with an earnest request, wishing to deal with him according to your advice and as I trust you. However, how you accommodate the boy and what I am required to give until Christmas, please inform me, so that I can prepare and keep faith at the right time; for although many crowns are said to be here with us, few have come to me, etc. So I am sending here 1 ducat; from which you should take the 6 batzen, likewise, along with the expenses, the rest for his needs, whether it be a little coat or a pair of linen trousers, and do so especially for God's sake, etc. In Chur, on July 8, 1550.
To the most honorable Mr. Bullinger, his most respected brother and lord.
These are the last words he wrote; for soon after, he was seized by the plague and passed away.
